text: I stared at the turn of the staircase for two seconds, then finally looked away.
Chasing after her would likely bring nothing but more humiliation.
I slid the bar back into place, took a deep breath, and went back to doing what needed to be done—like nothing had happened.
"…Just stay alive," I muttered to myself.
It sounded like self-mockery, or maybe a habit honed to a frightening degree.
I pulled the first-aid kit out from beneath the counter and pressed an alcohol-soaked cloth to the cut at the corner of my mouth.
The sting shot into my head like a needle, and I sucked in a sharp breath.
Gritting my teeth, I wrapped the bandage around twice and tied it tight. When I looked up again, my reflection in the glass looked like a battered stranger.
The chipped copper coin the drunk had flicked over was still on the counter, caught in a groove in the wood with a dull clink.
I didn’t pick it up. I righted the overturned chairs, wiped away the spilled wine, and swept the snow on the floor back out the door.
Only then did the guests dare move again, settling their tabs in low voices before leaving. Their footsteps were lighter than usual, as if afraid of disturbing the person upstairs.
I pressed the lid back onto the wine barrel, checked the lock, and made sure the short sword was still within easy reach beneath the counter.
—If he came back, at least I wouldn’t stand there taking the beating like before.
Only after all that did I finally sit down.
My fingers were still numb, my mouth still throbbing faintly, but what weighed on me more was something else:
She was far too familiar. Familiar like someone who had lived here for a long time—familiar enough to know where the key was without asking.
My eyes drifted, almost unconsciously, to the brass die on the counter.
It lay there quietly, its edges catching the firelight with a cold gleam.
I hadn’t touched it. And yet, as if nudged by something unseen, it rolled half a turn on its own—
"Thud."
A faint click of a door came from upstairs, and then everything fell silent.
A strange intuition crept over me: this wasn’t the first time she had stayed in that room, nor the first time she had climbed those stairs on a morning like this.
And I—maybe this wasn’t the first time I had endured the pain and cleaned up the inn as if nothing had happened.
